summary: This document is an email chain from November 2020 between defense attorney Susan Necheles and others, discussing a draft statement and a civil complaint. The emails focus on refuting allegations that Ghislaine Maxwell was present during Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of minors, citing specific victim claims and contradictory evidence like flight logs.

persons.name: Susan Necheles
persons.context: Attorney from Cassidy LLP corresponding about a draft statement and defending Ghislaine Maxwell against allegations of being present during abuse.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the defense arguments; her team disputes allegations that she was present during Epstein's sexual abuse of minors.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure whose abuse of young women and girls is acknowledged, but the defense argues Maxwell was not present for it.

connections.description: Maxwell worked out of Epstein's home and is defended against allegations of being present during his abuse.
Necheles is communicating as part of Maxwell's defense team, crafting statements to refute allegations.

events.title: Alleged abuse at Epstein's ranch
events.description: A victim alleges she was abused by Epstein at his ranch in the summer of 2002 and that Maxwell was present.

events.title: Flight to ranch
events.description: Flight logs indicate the victim's first trip to Epstein's ranch was in April 2003, after she turned 18, contradicting her abuse claim from summer 2002.

events.title: Alleged incident in New York townhouse
events.description: A victim claims Maxwell walked in on her performing oral sex on Epstein in his New York townhouse in 2005.

events.title: Discussion of draft statement
events.description: Email correspondence scheduling a call to discuss a draft statement and a civil complaint regarding allegations against Maxwell.

keyFacts: The defense argues Ghislaine Maxwell was not present during Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of minors, citing faulty memories due to the long passage of time.
Flight logs are used to contradict a victim's claim of abuse at Epstein's ranch in summer 2002, showing her first flight there was in April 2003 when she was 18.
Maxwell's defense states she worked out of Epstein's home but spent little time in his townhouse and staff were not allowed to roam private areas, disputing a 2005 incident claim.
The correspondence involves a civil complaint (Mary Doe v. Indyke) and discussions to avoid a Fatico hearing by acknowledging differing recollections without admitting allegations.
The defense acknowledges Epstein abused young women and girls but insists available evidence does not support Maxwell's presence during abuse of minors.
